How do I use the `currencyconverters` API to retrieve all currencies that have at least 100 VRSC in reserve?

The `currencyconverters` API actually retrieves all currencies that have at least 1000 VRSC in reserve, not 100 VRSC. Additionally, the currencies must also have a reserve ratio greater than 10% VRSC and have all listed currencies as reserves.

currencyconverters` API retrieves all currencies that have at least 1000 VRSC in reserve, are greater than 10% VRSC reserve ratio, and have all listed currencies as reserves
- **E.g. BTC ETH:**
```
verus -chain=VRSCTEST getcurrencyconverters btc eth
```
Will return all currencies that have btc/eth markets at or above the liquidity threshold.
What is the purpose of the `getcurrencyconverters` command?

The `getcurrencyconverters` command is used to retrieve all currencies that have markets at or above the liquidity threshold for the specified currencies. For example, `verus -chain=VRSCTEST getcurrencyconverters btc eth` will return all currencies that have btc/eth markets at or above the liquidity threshold. It does not have any other purpose than this.

currencyconverters` API retrieves all currencies that have at least 1000 VRSC in reserve, are greater than 10% VRSC reserve ratio, and have all listed currencies as reserves
- **E.g. BTC ETH:**
```
verus -chain=VRSCTEST getcurrencyconverters btc eth
```
Will return all currencies that have btc/eth markets at or above the liquidity threshold.
Can I use the `currencyconverters` API to retrieve all currencies that have a VRSC reserve ratio of less than 10%?
No, the `currencyconverters` API only retrieves currencies that have a VRSC reserve ratio greater than 10%, not less than 10%.

currencyconverters` API retrieves all currencies that have at least 1000 VRSC in reserve, are greater than 10% VRSC reserve ratio, and have all listed currencies as reserves
- **E.g. BTC ETH:**
```
verus -chain=VRSCTEST getcurrencyconverters btc eth
```
Will return all currencies that have btc/eth markets at or above the liquidity threshold.
